comments.value:
Hello

Is it possible to do some analysis on the types of ISP our user database are using e.g. MSN, Yahoo, AOL? It would be very helpful to know what the breakdown is. Or is it now easier for me to do this kind of segmentation in Communicator?

Grateful for your thoughts!

Sorry to chip in - you might be looking for one of these:

a) what ISPs (internet service providers) are our users using: https://www.google.com/analytics/reporting/networks?id=3492254
b) what email client software are our users using (ie outlook, pegasus or some web client) - this is v hard to find out (there might be something in communicator corp - i didn't find it in 4 minutes)
c) what email provider are our users using (ie how their email address ends, @yahoo.com, @msn.com, @gmail.com) - this is a relatively easy query (but probably one that runs for a bit) for kieran.

Janos, do you think it's possible to do it in Communicator?
As you imply, we can do it in the CMS (possibly directly in the database).

Morag, do you want a periodic report? Or just a one-off?
A one-off report would (probably - pending further discussion of requirements) take about 1/2 - 1 day.
A periodic report, running on a schedule, would take longer. Perhaps up to 2 days.

Am happy to discuss/schedule this work, but want to double-check that it's not functionality that you already have in Communicator (i.e. functionality that you've already paid for, elsewhere).

I will have a look in Communicator and see what I can do there, and if
it's not possible then I will ask you to have look in the UMS.

 

Thanks, all!

 

Morag Reavley
New Media Manager
London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games
23rd Floor, One Churchill Place
London E14 5LN
Direct line: +44 (0) 203 2012 160
Switchboard: +44 (0) 203 2012 000
www.london2012.com
www.twitter.com/london2012 
www.youtube.com/london2012  

 

________________________________
Propose closing this ticket.
Agreed

Hi Kathryn,

This is slightly mysterious. I just entered the text "Dinosaurs Not Allowed" into the Post event write-up box, saved it and re-opened it. It looks fine to me. Are you saying that when you publish the event all the copy disappears from the box again?

It would be very helpful if you could outline exactly what you are doing step-by-step, so that I can reproduce the problem.

Many thanks.

Hi Danny,

Yes, that’s what I mean – when I republished it last time, the copy disappears from that box. Which is probably why it currently isn’t showing up live.

Thanks,
Kathryn

[cid:image001.png@01CB60AC.B3A61AC0]
Could you paste the copy in here and I'll have a go from this end.

Here you go:

Dinosaurs Not Allowed 2010 – A Youth Traditional English Dance Showcase hit the streets of Weymouth on 25 September as a part of the London 2012 Cultural Olympiad's Count Me In weekend in the South West. Teams from across the region aged 5-25 danced to the delight of the general public. A key highlight this year was the invitation to the public and other dancers to have a go at another dance tradition and for the youngest dancers to mix with the oldest. We were joined by young musicians from Budmouth College supported by the local folk dancing/morris community and a swarthy band of pirates as stewards. Next year, the event will be held on 24 September – so come on down to Weymouth and see that young dancers are having fun and safely holding the English traditional dance alive. This was the second year we have had fine weather – you may even go away with a tan!

OK. That is published. And I have reproduced your problem. We are looking into it, but in the mean time make sure that you don't click between Post event write-up and Event long description. They appear to be conflicting.
Ok, thanks Danny!

Janos, would you mind taking a look at this? It looks like there might be only one id for the rich text editor, where perhaps two are needed (kit-rte_editor, perhaps?). Just try typing something into Post event write-up or Event long description and then clicking between them. Try it with any event, e.g. http://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/pages/editform/events/count-me-in-dinosaurs-not-allowed.php

Is there any way round this problem that you can see?
Looking at this one.

Kathryn,

Some feedback on this one. We appear to have made an error when we created the event edit screen in giving you two rich-text editing areas. The data entry code we use for these edit screens only supports a single rich-text area per page.

We could possibly upgrade the code, but this is likely to be non-trivial (possibly a day or more of coding).

Far and away the simplest solution would be to downgrade either "Event long description" or "Post event write-up" to plain text. 

Taking a look at events already in the system, I couldn't find any pages that actually contained anything more than plain text in either the description or the write-up and there are also not so many write-ups.

I suggest downgrading the "Post event write-up" field to plain text.

Would that be acceptable?

Hi Danny,

That sounds good to me. Liz, am copying you in to double check this is ok? We really don’t so many post-event write-ups anyway!

Kathryn
We do sometimes have pictures in that field – I don’t want both to be plain text!

Hi Danny,

Liz and I have just discussed this: Would it be possible to get rid of the ‘Post-even write-up’ box altogether and keep the ‘long description’ box in rich text? Then we can just go in and edit that box once the event is over (though to be fair, we very rarely get any feedback anyway!)

Thanks,
Kathryn

Janos, will this cause them to lose any post-event write-ups already entered or can ‘Post-even write-up’ safely be removed from the event entry screen without side effects? If so, please do it. Thanks.
They couldn't enter any post-event write-up I reckon.
There are some post-event write-ups already in the system, so it's probably not a good idea to remove the box altogether, but we have downgraded it to plain text.
That should be fine!
Marking as solved.

is the only thing that's related to the left hand navigation on the french site. I'm looking into it the moment.


For the rest I've created a new story for you: http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/687

We've looked into the paralympic sports order w/ Kieran. It's not in alphabetic order, but ordered by the navigation order set up in the English pages, which means that you're seeing them in the same order as in the English page.

We've two options here:

a) put them to alphabetic order (and ignore navigation order value) - that means names like 'Le cyclisme paralympique sur route' go to letter L instead of letter C.

b) set a specific order (which is different from the English order) - we have to do this manually at the moment, which means we're going to need a list of the correct order.
Marking as solved.

comments.value:
Hi Danny,

Can you please give me a call to discuss this?

Thanks,
Lakshmi

As discussed, we will analyse the logs from our end and send the information on user agents, actual website referrers, etc to you regularly. However, we need to understand how you would want us to send this information to you. Will it be through emails?

Thanks,
Lakshmi

Danny,

Not replying directly ;-) for fear of getting sucked in, but...

It probably enough to parse the logs on web01 and out the output the results as a HTML page inside a password protected dir (*) under the doc root ie. /www/html/new/london2012/404report/ 

As for the report itself, would be good to separate out:

- Direct 404 requests : these are outside our control
- Requests form robots:  also outside our control
- 404 with referring pages that we serve (ie. broken links on our pages) : these we /can/ do something about
- But excluded from the above should be any requests from the 'lookahead engine' of the buggy version of IE8 (or similar). 

In short the list of errors should be pretty small and limited to one we can actually fix ie. broken links in web pages we are serving. No harm in listing the rest but these should be separated out as they are outside of our control.

The point of this file is we can easily spot any error or broken link introduced into the site, a huge list of vague 404's is near useless, with or without referrers/agents (or at the very least will require a lot of manual effort to digest / investigate each time we look at it)

* a .htaccess file with the following in it will do the trick: (login/pass is any previous 2012 password combination ie. stratford/design or you could add new entry to /var/www/.htpasswd)

AuthName "Restricted Area New"
AuthType Basic
AuthUserFile /var/www/.htpasswd
AuthGroupFile /dev/null
require valid-user

We will take the report in whatever form is easiest for you send. Email is fine. Another possibility is to output the results as a HTML page inside a password protected directory on the site.

As for the report itself, it would be good to separate out:

- Direct 404 requests
- Requests from robots
- Requests from the 'lookahead engine' of the buggy version of IE8
- 404s with referring pages that we serve (ie. broken links on our pages)

The first three we cannot do much about, so although it would be useful to get some numbers, it is probably less useful to get a detailed breakdown.

The 404s originating from within the site (but excluding buggy IE8 requests) are the ones that we can and should fix, so for these we would want more detail.
Closing this one.

Hi all

In order to resolve this, we need to determine the location of the IP address from where the emails are originating: 213.120.228.150

First question: Do we know who this IP address belongs to?  Spoken with Deepak.  It appears we need to isolate the IP address first before it can be whitelisted.  According to Femi, the emails sent on behalf of gamesmaker.london2012.com come from the Atos solution.  The london2012.com domain has been delegated to the email server that sends emails via the accessibility form - so more than likely, 213.120.228.150 belongs to BT but this needs confirmation.

>> BT (this needs to be routed to BT via Servicedesk) : Can BT please check if this is the external IP address they own?

>> KitSite (Developers managing the accessibility form solution): As this issue involves the accessibility form, can you ensure the email is formed correctly?  In some cases, a malformed email arising from an incorrectly populated form has been known to be flagged as a Trojan/virus.

The emails should ideally be routed via Mimecast to ensure any rogue attachments are filtered and checked (Deepak can confirm this).

Deepak, can you:
a) liaise with KitSite/BT if need be.
b) engage with BT (if they own the email server which is sending these emails out) as necessary - copy emails to all cc'd above.

Thanks



Jagdeep Singh Bhambra
Service Engineering Manager
Internet Technology Services

comments.value: Provisional date.
We would like to move this date back. We need access to an Omnia 2 to start work on this.

Can I just confirm, are we still wanting to target the Omnia 2? The new Samsung Galaxy is Android based and according to recent news reports Samsung are now pushing their Android smart phones ahead of the Windows-based phones like the Omnia.
Checking and will come back to you asap
Our view is that the Omnia is yesterday’s phone and the Galaxy/Android phones are the more important from the Samsung point of view – so better to focus on those.

This is very good news. This essentially means we are targeting the same webkit browser engine as the iPhone. I will mark this as solved, but there is a related ticket which we will be returning to shortly: http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/437

I've spent some time trying to figure out what's going on - and starting to believe it's a crossdomain.xml issue, or in English: a flash issue. I can spend more time trying to pinpoint the problem, but it's very time consuming, and may end up having to change the swf. Probably those who produced the flash file could sort this out much quicker than we do.

Details: flash is very restrictive about fetching data from different subdomains - and in webcams there are quite a few subdomains are involved:

- the page itself on "london2012.com" (or www.london2012.com)
- the webcam flash is located at "map.london2012.com"
- the csv file containing the different webcam picture filenames is located "webcams.map.london2012.com"
- the pictures are at "cloudfront.webcams.map.london2012.com"

If for some reason any of the rights aren't right (for caching or different reasons), the page doesn't load properly.

Are you therefore still investigating how to fix it?

I can spend more time trying to pinpoint the problem, but it's very time consuming, and may end up having to change the swf. Probably those who produced the flash file could sort this out much quicker than we do."

In other words, he can spend more time on it, but it may be quite a lot of time (a day or two, rather than an hour or two) and it may lead him to the same conclusion, i.e. the flash file needs to be tweaked.

It may be sensible to forward his comments to Stamen for their feedback. If his diagnosis is correct, then they may be a better position than us to fix the issue.
